answers.author: Barry Crook
answers.text:
We use a system from a vendor called "Best Year Yet"  (http://www.bestyearyet.com/index.html) for our Council's /Top Ten goals that is a pretty typical planning process. It uses a series of questions to prompt the selection of guidelines, new paradigm or vision, major focus and Top Ten Goals. The questions/exercises are: 1. What did I accomplish?
2. What were my biggest disappointments?
3a. What did I learn?
3b. Guidelines for Next Year
4a. How do I limit myself and how can I stop?
4b. What do I say about myself to explain my failures?
4c. What is my limiting paradigm?
4d. What is my new paradigm?
5. What are my personal values?
6. What roles do I play at work?
7. Which role is my major focus for next year?
8. What are my goals for each role?
9. What are my top ten goals for next year?
10. How can I make sure I achieve them?
I have used another methodology in several organizations and use it here in Aspen with departments/work teams. It is a series of created lists that build off of each other. The method slows down the urge to go from "I have a problem" to "I have a solution" and explore the thinking it greater depth. It needs to be facilitated by someone who will help folks slow down and reveal their thinking -- the lists are: 
1. Assessments
2. Observations
3. Premise Identification
4. Issue Identification
5. Objectives and Goals Identification
6. Strategy Identification
7. Resource Identification
8. Accountability Identification
A word documentation is attached that shows the details for that process.

answers.author: Susan Kulbersh
answers.text:
Before a team can set goals, they should define their mission or purpose. FranklinCovey has a mission builder for a personal, a family as well as a Team mission.  The link below will provide a guide to creating a mission statement for your team. A clear mission statement can build unity, purpose, commitment, and clarity of vision—all of which are vital to your team’s success.  Creating a mission statement uncovers core values and highest goals. This process will help unite your team around a common sense of purpose and mission. From here, setting goals will be a lot clearer as they will be aligned with the mission of the Team.
http://www.franklincovey.com/msb/

author: Tracy Corman
text:
Does anyone have a good template for a team goal setting instrument.  We are looking for an excercise we can send to our council prior to their retreat to help them develop their goals for the upcoming year.  Many of our council members are newly elected, and have not gone through this exercise before.  I would appreciate any suggestions for sources, or templates you can share.
Thank you!
title: Goal setting instruments
